items.title: Virginia’s Governor-elect Wants a Say Over Leadership at U.Va.
items.summary: Abigail Spanberger, a Democrat, told the university’s board that the choice of a new president, to replace one pushed out by Republicans over the summer, should be delayed until she is in office.

items.title: He Died at a School for Disabled People. Decades Later, His Brother Sought Answers.
items.summary: John Scott was rarely spoken of in his family after he was placed in an institution. After a half-century, his youngest brother set out to learn who he was and what happened to him.

items.title: How Much Screen Time Is Your Child Getting at School? We Asked 350 Teachers.
items.summary: Even as schools have banned phones, a Times survey shows how the pandemic-era practice of giving students their own laptops and tablets is here to stay.

items.title: Justice Department to Investigate Protests at Turning Point Event at Berkeley
items.summary: The announcement came a day after protesters confronted attendees of a campus event hosted by Turning Point USA, the conservative group founded by Charlie Kirk.

items.title: Democrat’s Win May Upend a Conservative Push in Virginia Universities
items.summary: Supporters of Abigail Spanberger, Virginia’s governor-elect, say they expect her to reverse efforts to impose conservative priorities on the state’s prestigious public university system.

items.title: Robert A.M. Stern Is Still Dreaming of a Fresh New York
items.summary: The sharp-tongued architect and professor built Manhattan’s most luxurious towers, but his new book shuttles from Billionaires’ Row to the Bronx. (Plus, what he thinks of Rem and Zaha.)

items.title: Cornell Reaches Deal With Trump Administration to Restore Research Funds
items.summary: The Ivy League university had warned of layoffs after the Trump administration stripped it of funds this year. The cuts were among the deepest in higher education.

items.title: Among Mamdani’s Many Upcoming Challenges: Fixing New York City’s Schools
items.summary: Zohran Mamdani, the mayor-elect, will encounter dwindling enrollment, lackluster reading scores and federal officials spoiling for a fight.

items.title: For the Children of Performa, the Sound of Art Is a Buzz and a Growl
items.summary: An arts festival taps third- and fourth-graders to teach adults a thing or two about authenticity.

items.title: Jury Awards $10 Million to Abigail Zwerner, Teacher Shot by 6-Year-Old Student
items.summary: The teacher, Abigail Zwerner, was shot in the hand and chest by a first grade student who brought his mother’s gun to class in 2023.

items.title: Trump Pressure Risking Free Speech at University of California, Judge Warns
items.summary: A federal judge said that faculty members were being affected in their teaching and research by the Trump administration’s pressure campaign.

items.title: John Cleary, Wounded in Kent State Shooting, Dies at 74
items.summary: He was shot in 1970 by the National Guard during a student protest over the Vietnam War that left four dead in Ohio. A photo of him lying on the ground and bleeding made the cover of Life magazine.

items.title: Virginia Teen Narrowly Defeats His Former Civics Teacher in County Election
items.summary: Cameran Drew, 19, defeated his former high school government teacher, Kenneth Bell, by 10 votes for a seat on the Surry County Board of Supervisors this week. There are no hard feelings.

items.title: How Is Trump Changing Colleges and Universities? Tell Us.
items.summary: There has been a shift in campus culture. We want to hear from faculty members across the United States.

items.title: Texas A&M Tightens Rules on Talking About Race and Gender in Classes
items.summary: The university system will ban advocacy of “race or gender ideology, or topics related to sexual orientation or gender identity” without approval.

items.title: Indiana Professor Removed From Class Over White Supremacy Lesson
items.summary: The professor will no longer be able to teach a class on diversity after she showed students a diagram that included the “Make America Great Again” slogan as an example of white supremacy.

items.title: Government Shutdown Ends and Federal Workers Return
items.summary: Government employees were expecting to see paychecks again as early as Nov. 20 after six weeks in limbo.

items.title: He Helped Cities Anticipate Damage From Storms
items.summary: Austin Becker developed an early warning system to protect critical infrastructure from storms. His project’s funding was eliminated in April.

items.title: Visiting Leiden, Canals and Charm Without the Crowds of Amsterdam
items.summary: Leiden, a city whose university is often called the Oxford of the Netherlands, features museums, gardens, murals and plenty of ways to stretch your mind.

items.title: College Romance Books That Will Make You Swoon
items.summary: The explosive potential of those years makes every emotion more intense — and a perfect combo for rich storytelling.
